sourcesContent:
import React from 'react'; import Layout from '../layout/Layout'; import '../../styles/ProjectDetail.css'; // Import images import routerImage from '../../assets/images/RaspAp_TravelRouter_v2.jpeg'; import raspPiImagerImage from '../../assets/images/RaspPiImager.png'; import raspiConfigImage from '../../assets/images/Raspi-config_window.png'; import raspAPAdminLoginImage from '../../assets/images/RaspAP_AdminLogin.png'; import wlan1ConfigImage from '../../assets/images/WLAN1_Config_RaspAP.png'; import passwordResetImage from '../../assets/images/PasswordReset_RaspAP_Hotspot.png'; import countryCodeConfigImage from '../../assets/images/RaspAP_Hotspot_CountryCodeConfig.png'; const TravelRouterPage: React.FC = () => { return (

Building a Raspberry Pi Travel Router

By Ethan Reese August 7, 2023

My complete travel router setup using a Raspberry Pi 4

My purpose for building this travel router was to solve the problem of hotel Wi-Fi that limits connections to one device and to create a secure network while traveling. In this tutorial, I'll walk you through how I built a portable travel router using a Raspberry Pi that solved these problems.
My solution to guest portal login pages was to use a mini touch screen and keyboard to manually pass the login pages to the Pi. I'm currently working on an automated solution for this.

This tutorial is a work in progress. I'll be adding more sections as I go.

What You'll Need

  • A laptop or desktop computer
  • Raspberry Pi (I used a Pi 4, but Pi 3B+ works too)
  • MicroSD card (16GB or larger recommended)
  • USB Wi-Fi adapter (for dual Wi-Fi capability) (I used this one but there are better options)
  • USB-C 5v Power Supply (for powering the Pi)
  • A monitor, keyboard, and mouse (my prefered method)
  • Mini screen and keyboard (for passing guest portal login pages) (I used this screen and this keyboard)
  • Ethernet cable (optional for connecting via ssh)
  • Portable power bank (optional)

Step 1: Raspberry Pi OS Setup

Download Raspberry Pi Imager

First, download the Raspberry Pi Imager from the official Raspberry Pi site.

Once downloaded, open the imager and select the Raspberry Pi OS (64-bit) image. Select the SD card and click "Next", then "Write" to flash the image to the SD card.

Raspberry Pi Imager Settings

After flashing, insert the SD card into your Raspberry Pi, connect it to your monitor, keyboard, and mouse, and power it on. Alternatively, you can connect it to your computer via Ethernet and use the terminal to configure it (official documentation here).

Step 2: RaspAP Installation

I chose to use RaspAP for the router's operating system because of it's ease of use and immediate VPN and ad-blocking capabilities.

Update OS, Set WiFi Country, Invoke RaspAP's Quick Installer


{`# Confirm OS is up to date
sudo apt-get update
sudo apt-get full-upgrade
sudo reboot`}

Set the WiFi country to the country where you're located. 


{`# Set WiFi country
sudo raspi-config`}

Raspberry Pi WiFi Country Configuration

  • Select "Localisation Options"
  • Select "Change WiFi Country"
  • Select your country

Invoke RaspAP's Quick Installer. 


{`# Invoke RaspAP's Quick Installer
curl -sL https://install.raspap.com | bash`}

At the end of the install process, accept the prompt to reboot your system. The default configuration is as follows:

  • IP address: 10.3.141.1
  • Username: admin
  • Password: secret
  • DHCP range: 10.3.141.50 â€” 10.3.141.254
  • SSID: RaspAP
  • Password: ChangeMe
For the offical documentation on installing RaspAP, see here.

Step 4: Configure RaspAP

Now that RaspAP is running and the second Wi-Fi antenna drivers are installed, you'll need to access RaspAP's web interface to configure it.
Navigate to 10.9.141.1 in your web browser on your Pi. The default username is "admin" and the default password is "secret".

It is likely that the builtin antenna is faster and has better range than the external antenna. This means that we need to switch which antenna is used for a hotspot and which is used to connect to the internet.
If this is not the case for your setup, you can skip this step.

Go to the "Hotspot" tab on the left side of the screen and set the "Interface" to the external antenna (wlan1 likely).

Go to the "Security" tab at the top and change the password for the hotspot.

Go to the "Advanced" tab at the top and confirm the country code is set to the country where you're located.

Next Steps

In the next part of this tutorial, I'll cover:

  • Setting up a VPN for secure browsing
  • Automating the guest portal login process (when a password/code isn't required)
  • Configuring ad-blocking with Pi-hole
 ); }; export default TravelRouterPage;
